_meanings:
strong in 

cavalry, superior in horses.

a guardian of horses, commander of
cavalry.

a troop of horse
men, cavalry.

riding or mounted on
a horse.

{1} a horseman, rider.
{2} one who is fighting. 
{3} a ride.

{3} a term in
surgery for a particular fracture of
the bones.

{1} <ab>N.</ab> of a bird.
{2} a general of the army of the gods.

_gram:
[{#aSvaSca KarIca aSvAca KaraSca vA#} 
{#tAByAM jAyate puMvadBAvaH#} <ls>Tv.</ls>]

_meanings:
{2} <ab>N.</ab> of a metre
containing four lines of sixteen 
syllables in each.

<ab>N.</ab> of a plant
Physalis Flexuosa Lin;

{1} <ab>N.</ab> of a
demon who was a foe of Viṣṇu,
more commonly called Haya-grīva.

<ab>N.</ab> of a place of pilgrimage near
Kānyakubja on the Gaṅgā.

one who has the charge
of a drove of grazing horses; a 
horseherd.

{1} a kind of reed, Saccharum
Spontaneum Lin.

{2} the tail or
hair of a horse.

<ab>Ved.</ab>
based on horses, standing on
horses, {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} on a carriage drawn by
horses.

<ab>Ved.</ab> based on
horses, having its origin in horses
(wealth); distinguished by horses.

the natural enmity 
between a horse and a buffalo.

‘horse-destroying,’ a kind of Oleander, Nerium
Odorum Ait.

having the head or face of
a horse.

a horse-faced 
creature, a Kinnara or celestial 
chorister; (according to others) a kind
of demigod distinct from the
preceding.

a horse-sacrifice; {#yaTASvameDaH#}
{#kraturAw sarvapApApanodanaH#} <ls>Ms. 11. 261.</ls>
[In Vedic times this sacrifice was 
performed by kings desirous of offspring; but
subsequently it was performed only by
kings and implied that he who 
instituted it was a conqueror and king of kings.
A horse was turned loose to wander at
will for a year, attended by a guardian;
when the horse entered a foreign country,
the ruler was bound either to submit or
to fight. In this way the horse returned
at the end of a year, the guardian 
obtaining or enforcing the submission of 

princes whom he brought in his train.
After the successful return of the horse,
the rite called Aśvamedha was 
performed amidst great rejoicings. It was 
believed that the performance of 100 such 
sacrifices would lead to the attainment of the
seat or world of Indra, who is, therefore,
always represented as trying to prevent
the completion of the hundredth sacrifice].

<ab>N.</ab> of the thirteenth book of
the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa.

fit for a horse-sacrifice, or
relating to it.

a horse fit
for the {%Aśvamedha%} sacrifice.

the
fourteenth parvan in the 
Mahābhārata; {#tato'SvameDikaM parva proktaM tacca caturdaSaM#}
<ls>Mb.</ls>

{2} having horses yoked to it (as a
carriage); {#raTenASvayujA#} <ls>Rām.</ls>

{1} <ab>N.</ab> of a constellation, the head of
Aries.

the
post to which the sacrificial horse
was bound.

{2} joining or
reaching as quickly as horses.

the keeper or rider of a horse, a
groom.

the best or lord
of horses; {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} {#uccEHSravas#}.
a sign or mark of a horse.

<ab>N.</ab> of a species of the
Vikṛti metre.

a stud of horses
and mares.

{1} skilled in taming or
managing horses.
a pillar to tie a horse.

a 

manual or text-book of veterinary 
science.

having the head of a
horse, an epithet of Nārāyaṇa.

the natural enmity between
a horse and a jackal.

a set
or team of six horses.

<ab>Ved.</ab> (<ls>P. VIII. 3. 110</ls> and
<ls>Mbh.</ls>) gaining or procuring horses,
giving horses.

coachmanship,
charioteership, management of horses
and chariots; {#sUtAnAmaSvasAraTyaM#}  
<ls>Ms. 10. 47.</ls>

{1} praised
sincerely for (the gift of) horses.

{2} whose praise for (giving) horses
is agreeable and true.

relating to the praise of the
sacrificial horse.

a stable or stall for
horses.

{2} to be traversed
by a horse; <ls>Rv. 9. 96. 2.</ls>

{1} the desire or 
intention of a horse.
